metadata.case_name: Criminal Appeals Nos. 53 and 54 of 1956 (State of Bihar v. Mahesh Desai and Mahesh Desai v. Respondents)

facts.text: Murder of Nand Kumar Chaubey, a peon of a colliery in Bagdigi, committed in the course of a serious riot on February 20, 1954, resulting from differences between two rival labour-unions in connection with a strike.

Prosecution launched on first information of Ram Naresh Pandey against 28 persons; most accused under various sections of IPC including s.302 for actual participation in murder; Mahesh Desai accused only under s.302/109 IPC for abetting by speeches and exhortations at meetings the day previous to the murder.

In FIR, Mahesh Desai held meetings advocating closing Bagdigi cable plant, come plant and assaulting dalals; on Friday morning at 11 a.m. told labourers to stop work; evening at 6:30 p.m. at Bagdigi Mahabir Asthan Chala collected 120-125 labourers, exhorted them to prevent work resumption; at 7:30 p.m. near pit No.10 said 'It is necessary for us to finish the dalals for achieving victory. You remain prepared for this' and to Phagu, Jalo, Haricharan Dusadh 'Finish all. What will happen will be seen'.
Next day rioting, Phagu, Jalo, Haricharan Dusadh chased Nand Kumar Chaubey, Phagu gave pharsa blow, Haricharan lathi blow, he fell dead.

Public Prosecutor applied for withdrawal u/s 494 CrPC on December 6, 1954, against Mahesh Desai only, during commitment stage before Magistrate, before any evidence taken; ground: evidence available insufficient, meagre, single dubious item unlikely to establish prima facie case.
Subordinate Judge-Magistrate of Dhanbad granted consent, discharged Mahesh Desai u/s 494 CrPC.
Order upheld by Sessions Judge of Manbhum-Singhbhum of Purulia on revision petition by first informant and widow of deceased.
Patna High Court (Chief Justice) set aside discharge order on revision, directed Magistrate to record evidence and consider prima facie case.
Special leave appeals to Supreme Court: by State (Appeal No.53) and Mahesh Desai (Appeal No.54).

legal_issues.text: Whether, on application for withdrawal u/s 494 CrPC by Public Prosecutor on ground of insufficiency/meagreness of reliable evidence available, it is improper exercise of discretion for Court to grant consent before evidence taken, if reasonably satisfied evidence unlikely to result in conviction.
Whether application u/s 494 CrPC for withdrawal lies in commitment (preliminary inquiry) stage of Sessions triable case.

petitioner_arguments.text: View of High Court Chief Justice erroneous; legally permissible for Magistrate to grant consent u/s 494 before evidence if satisfied Public Prosecutor's view on insufficiency proper; not surrender to Prosecutor; s.494 gives executive discretion to Prosecutor subject to judicial consent on broad grounds.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.494 CrPC; Bawa Faqir Singh v. King Emperor

petitioner_arguments.text: s.494 applies to commitment stage in Sessions cases; no distinction between inquiry and trial limiting it; historical evolution confirms wide scope.

respondent_arguments.text: Where withdrawal sought on ground of no/insufficient evidence, Court must record evidence judicially before consenting; otherwise improper, tantamount to pre-judging sufficiency.

In Sessions triable case, s.494 withdrawal not available in commitment stage; only after reaches trial stage, as per wording 'tried by jury before verdict, in other cases before judgment'; 'tried' excludes inquiry.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.494 CrPC; s.4(k) CrPC definition of inquiry

court_reasoning.text: s.494 enabling, vests initiative/discretion in Public Prosecutor; Court gives consent via judicial discretion to check improper exercise/abuse, not full judicial determination on evidence; can rely on available material like FIR/police statements without recording evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Judicial function is to satisfy executive not improperly exercised; not prima facie trial determination.

court_reasoning.text: Not limited to cases with evidence requiring judicial consideration; Court can consent pre-evidence if satisfied unlikely to convict; engrafting exception for insufficiency grounds impermissible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Available evidence (FIR etc.) to be considered, but no mandatory recording.

court_reasoning.text: s.494 wide/general; applies to all stages including commitment inquiry in Sessions cases; no discrimination vs jury cases; 'tried' not limited to post-inquiry; history (1872 s.61, 1882 s.494) confirms covers inquiry/trial.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Result discharge/acquittal per stage, before charge framed.

court_reasoning.text: On merits, evidence against Mahesh Desai meagre (second-hand in FIR via Jadubans Tiwary etc.); Public Prosecutor's view reasonable; no better material shown; High Court erred in interfering.
court_reasoning.key_observation: FIR allegations exhortations, but chain hearsay.

holdings.text: Court may grant consent u/s 494 CrPC to withdrawal before evidence recorded, if reasonably satisfied on available material that evidence unlikely to result in conviction and Prosecutor's discretion properly exercised.
s.494 CrPC applies to commitment (preliminary inquiry) stage in Sessions triable cases; no exclusion based on 'tried' or inquiry vs trial distinction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bawa Faqir Singh v. The King Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: s.494 gives general executive discretion to Public Prosecutor subject to Court consent on many grounds; Prosecutor officer of Court.
Withdrawal legitimately for reasons not confined to judicial prospects.
Withdrawal legitimately for reasons not confined to judicial prospects.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: s.494 central: withdrawal by PP with Court consent; results in discharge/acquittal per stage; judicial consent checks abuse; applies all stages including commitment; distinguished from inquiry/trial provisions.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Prosecution under s.302/109 against Mahesh Desai for abetment.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure (historical)
statutes_cited.relevance: Evolution shows widening scope, covers inquiry stages.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed both appeals, set aside Patna High Court order, restored Magistrate's order discharging Mahesh Desai; held s.494 permits consent pre-evidence on insufficiency grounds and applies to commitment stage.
outcome.relief_granted: Discharge of Mahesh Desai restored; prosecution against him withdrawn.

key_quotes.text: "Section 494 of the Code of Criminal Procedure gives a general executive discretion to the Public Prosecutor to withdraw from the prosecution subject to the consent of the Court, which may be determined on many possible grounds."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of s.494 as executive discretion checked judicially.

key_quotes.text: "The judicial function, therefore, implicit in the exercise of the judicial discretion for granting the consent would normally mean that the Court has to satisfy itself that the executive function of the Public Prosecutor has not been improperly exercised."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies Court's role: prevent abuse, not pre-trial.

key_quotes.text: "We are, therefore, unable, with great respect, to subscribe to the view taken by the learned Chief Justice... that where the application is on the ground of inadequacy of evidence requiring judicial consideration, it would be manifestly improper for the Court to consent to withdrawal before recording the evidence."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Directly overrules HC view on pre-evidence consent.
